category_ipcc_2006: 3.B.2 - Cropland
description: BEF for expansion of stem volume to aboveground biomass
region: India (Cachar District, latitude 24?22`and 25?8`N; longitude 92?24`and 93 ?15`E). The climate is sub-tropical, warm and humid climate with average rainfall of 2390 mm, most of which is received during the southwest monsoon season (MayeSeptember). The mean maximum temperature ranges from 25.4 ?C (January) to 33.5  ?C (August). The mean minimum temperature ranges from 11.2 ?C (January) to 25.3 ?C (August). Soil: silty clay and loamy soil while coarse sandy loamy is found in hillock land. In fact the soil of the region is mixture of alluvial, sandy loam, muddy loam superimposed upon stones, gravels and conglomerates.
technical_reference: Kalita, R. M., et al. (2015). "Allometric equations for estimating above- and belowground biomass in Tea (Camellia sinensis (L.) O. Kuntze) agroforestry system of Barak Valley, Assam, northeast India." Biomass & Bioenergy 83: 42-49.

category_ipcc_2006: 1.B.1.a.i - Underground mines
description: Fugitive emissions from underground mining activities Average (weighted based on coal production)
region: Measurements were carried out on 81 degree-I mines.  These mines were located in different coalfields within eastern and central India. The coalfields within these measurements were: Raniganj, Jharia, East-Bokaro, Mand-Raigarh, Pranhita Godavari, Sohagpur, Ib Valley, Pench-Kannan, Bisrampur, Johilla and Hasdeo, India. "Degree-I" underground seam refers to a coal seams in which the percentage of methane in the general body of air does not exceed 0.1 and the rate of emission of methane does not exceed one cubic meter per tonne of coal produced. (Reg 2(12A), Coal Mines Regulations, 1957, DGMS, India).
technical_reference: Singh A.K., Singh U., Panigrahi D.C., Singh J. (2021). Updated emission inventory of underground coal mining activities based on 2019 IPCC Refinement, PMRC Working Paper: 01/2021

category_ipcc_2006: 1.B.1.a.i - Underground mines
description: Fugitive methane emissions from underground coal mining activities from Degree-I mines. Average (weighted based on coal production)
region: Measurements were carried out on 81 degree-I mines.  These mines were located in different coalfields within eastern and central India. The coalfields within these measurements were: Raniganj, Jharia, East-Bokaro, Mand-Raigarh, Pranhita Godavari, Sohagpur, Ib Valley, Pench-Kannan, Bisrampur, Johilla and Hasdeo, India. "Degree-I" underground seam refers to a coal seams in which the percentage of methane in the general body of air does not exceed 0.1 and the rate of emission of methane does not exceed one cubic meter per tonne of coal produced. (Reg 2(12A), Coal Mines Regulations, 1957, DGMS, India).
technical_reference: Singh A.K., Singh U., Panigrahi D.C., Singh J. (2021). Updated emission inventory of underground coal mining activities based on 2019 IPCC Refinement, PMRC Working Paper: 01/2021
